questions.text: Which of the following method (shown in the image) for the demonstration of serum haptoglobin?
questions.solution:
• Direct measurement of HAPTOGLOBIN is done by:
    • Cellulose acetate electrophoresis
    • Radial immunodiffusion
  • The above image shown is of Radial immunodiffusion. (Choice B)
    • Upper most image shows low concentrations
    • Middle image shows normal concentrations
    • Bottom one shows increased concentrations

Why the other options are incorrect:

  • The electrophoresis for the demonstration of serum haptoglobin: (choice A)
  1. Serum from case of HEMOLYTIC ANEMIA with no haptoglobin (the added hemoglobin is demonstrated as a band in the beta globulin position)
  2. Normal serum with added haemoglobin: there are bands in the Beta globulin (haemoglobin) and Alpha 2 globulin (haemoglobin-haptoglobin complex) positions, respectively.

The pattern of serum electrophoresis is shown.

A - albumin; alpha 1&2 and beta components of globulin.

  • The method of fluorescent screening test is for G6PD deficiency. (Choice C)
  • HPLC - High chromatography liquid chromatography is used for the Investigation of patients with a suspected haemoglobinopathy. (Choice D)

KEY TAKEAWAYS:

  • Radial Immunodiffusion (RID) is used for the direct quantitative measurement of serum haptoglobin.
  • The image depicts three rows:
    • The top row shows low concentrations of haptoglobin.
    • The middle row represents normal concentrations.
    • The bottom row demonstrates increased concentrations, visible by the diameter of the immunodiffusion rings.
    • This method relies on the antigen-antibody reaction forming visible precipitation rings, whose size is proportional to the protein concentration.

questions.text: Choose the correct inherited disorder from the following which shows the following type of abnormal neutrophils in the given photomicrograph from a blood film.
questions.solution:
There are a few rare inherited disorders that are manifest by abnormal neutrophils.

ALDER-REILLY ANOMALY

  • The granules are very large, are discrete, stain deep red and may obscure the nucleus
  • Mnemonic: GRANULES
    • G: Gargoyle-like facies (features seen in mucopolysaccharidoses).
    • R: Reilly bodies (coarse granules in leukocytes, resembling toxic granulation).
    • A: Autosomal recessive inheritance pattern.
    • N: Neurological issues (sometimes associated due to underlying storage diseases).
    • U: Urinary excretion of mucopolysaccharides (characteristic of storage disorders).
    • L: Lysosomal storage disease association (e.g., Hurler or Hunter syndromes).
    • E: Enzyme deficiency causing buildup of mucopolysaccharides.
    • S: Systemic manifestations (including skeletal and organ involvement).
  • Alder-Reilly neutrophils function normally

CHEDIAK-HIGASHI SYNDROME (autosomal recessive)

  • The granules are very large, are discrete, stain deep red and may obscure the nucleus
  • Mnemonic: CHEDIAK
    • C - CNS/neurological defect
    • HE - Hemorrhage
    • DI - Decrease immunity
    • A - Albinism (silver gray hair)
    • A - Autosomal recessive
    • K - Coarse granules in neutrophils
  • There is a functional defect that is manifested by susceptibility to severe infection.

PELGER HUET ANOMALY (autosomal dominant disorder) - it is a benign, inherited blood disorder which affects nuclei of neutrophils. (Choice C)

  • Reduced number of nuclear segments and coarse chromatin.
  • The nuclei may be bilobed, peanut shaped or dumbbell shaped instead of normal trilobed shape.
  • These neutrophils have only two discrete equal-sized lobes connected by a thin chromatin bridge.
  • Eosinophils and basophils are also hyposegmented

Key Takeaways: The picture shows abnormally large, discrete, deep red-staining granules in neutrophils, characteristic of Chediak-Higashi Syndrome.

  • This is an autosomal recessive disorder associated with:
    • Neurological defects, albinism, and decreased immunity, leading to increased susceptibility to severe infections.
    • A functional defect in neutrophils despite their abnormal appearance.

Other similar disorders like Alder-Reilly anomaly and Pelger-Huet anomaly have distinct features but lack the combination of large granules, systemic symptoms (e.g., albinism), and functional defects found in Chediak-Higashi Syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following parameter is not used to detect blood doping?
questions.solution:
BLOOD DOPING (INDUCED ERYTHROCYTHAEMIA)

  • It is the practice of increasing the number of red blood cells through an intravenous infusion of blood, thereby enhancing performance in sports through the increase in red blood cell mass with an increased oxygen-carrying capacity.
  • Erythropoietin can be used to induce erythropoiesis.
  • Blood doping is an illegal practice as it provides an unfair advantage of endurance and performance over other athletes.
  • It is also potentially dangerous due to the abnormal increase in red cell mass and the risk of acquiring infection from contaminated blood.
  • The sports administrative bodies collect blood profiles on individual athletes and these are monitored over time so changes in blood -parameters due to doping can be detected.

Why the other options are incorrect:

  • Red cell parameters (Choice C)
    • Most red cell parameters can be used to indirectly detect blood doping. This is due to the increased Hb either as a result of a raised erythropoietin or a direct transfusion of red blood cells in cases of blood doping.
  • Reticulocytes (choice B)
    • Erythropoietin causes increased production of erythroblasts and immature reticulocytes, and accelerates their release from the bone marrow into peripheral blood. The mean haemoglobin content of the reticulocyte fraction is also raised.
  • Haemoglobin concentration and haematocrit (choice A)
    • Exogenous erythropoietin and intravenous infusion of blood both increase the Hb and Hct.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Blood doping is an illegal practice aimed at enhancing athletic performance by increasing red blood cell mass, often through erythropoietin use or blood transfusion, leading to elevated oxygen-carrying capacity. Key parameters used to detect blood doping include hematocrit (packed cell volume), reticulocyte count (reflecting accelerated red cell production), and mean corpuscular volume (MCV), all of which monitor changes in red cell mass. Platelet count, however, is unrelated to blood doping, as it measures clotting elements rather than red cell indices. Sports organizations track athlete's blood profiles over time to detect suspicious changes indicative of doping.

choices.text: A - Plasmodium falciparum, B - Leishmaniasis, C - Microfilaria, D - Trypansoma
A - Leishmaniasis, B - Plasmodium falciparum, C - Microfilaria, D - Typansoma
A - Leishmaniasis, B - Plasmodium falciparum, C - Trypansoma, D - Microfilaria
A - Plasmodium falciparum, B - Leishmaniasis, C - Trypansoma, D - Microfilaria

questions.text: Match the following blood parasites to their peripheral smear microscopy.
questions.solution:
KEY TAKEAWAYS:

  • Plasmodium falciparum: Shows delicate, fine cytoplasmic rings (early trophozoites) with 1-2 chromatin dots. Late stages include banana-shaped gametocytes and rarely seen schizonts.
  • Leishmaniasis: Characterized by amastigote forms (LD bodies), which are small (2-4 μm), with a pale blue cytoplasm, a pink-stained nucleus, and a rod-shaped kinetoplast at right angles to the nucleus. Seen in macrophages or free in aspirates.
  • Trypanosoma (Chagas disease): T. cruzi trypomastigotes appear elongated with flagellum, undulating membranes, and often a C-shape. Non-motile amastigotes may also be observed.
  • Microfilaria: Wuchereria bancrofti microfilariae are 300 μm long with a hyaline sheath, distinct central nuclei, and absent nuclei at the tail tip.

choices.text: It gives positive pearls reaction for ionised iron
It is seen in megaloblastic anemia
Aggregates of fragments of ribosomal RNA precipitated throughout the cytoplasm of circulating RBCs

questions.text: Which of the following statement is incorrect about the RBC abnormality shown in the arrow?
questions.solution:
• The given photomicrograph of peripheral smear is of thalassemia.
  • And the arrowed structure shows BASOPHILIC STIPPLING or PUNCTATE BASOPHILIA meaning the presence of numerous basophilic granules distributed

KEY TAKEAWAYS:

  • Basophilic stippling refers to the presence of basophilic granules in the cytoplasm of RBCs, caused by the precipitation of ribosomal RNA, and does not contain iron, so it will not give a positive Pearls reaction for iron.
  • Pappenheimer bodies, which are another type of RBC abnormality, contain iron and would give a positive Pearls reaction.

questions.text: The morphological abnormality observed on blood film examination suggest which type of acquired hemolytic anemia? Match the following.
questions.solution:
FRAGMENTATION SYNDROME: Red blood cells, when subjected to physical or mechanical trauma in the circulation may undergo fragmentation. This causes intravascular hemolysis and results in hemolytic anemias. These are known as fragmentation syndrome.

  • CLASSIFICATION
    • Macroangiopathic (large vessels) hemolytic anemia
    • Microangiopathic (capillaries) hemolytic anemia
  • LABORATORY FINDINGS (for both macro & microangiopathic hemolytic anemia)
    • Hemoglobin: Decreased. Anemia is mild to moderate.
    • Peripheral smear:
      • RBCs: They show fragmented red blood cells (known as SCHISTOCYTES), polychromasia, with or without nucleated red blood cells and microspherocytes. The fragmented red cells assume different shapes like "triangular cells", "burr cells", "helmet cells" and are the hallmark of diagnosis.
      • WBCs: Normal/increased.
      • Platelets: Thrombocytopenia

COLD ANTIBODY INDUCED AUTOIMMUNE HEMOLYTIC ANEMIA: Caused by so-called cold agglutinins.(Antibodies bind to red cell antigens at low temperatures (4-18°C), i.e. avidity of red cell to antibody increases as the temperature falls)

  • Peripheral smear:
    • RBCs - shows normocytic normochromicanemia, polychromasia. It characteristically shows red cell clumping or agglutination along with nucleated rbcs and spherocytes.
    • WBCs & Platelets - within limts

PAROXYSMAL COLD HEMOGLOBINURIA: Cold Hemolysins Type (Donath-Landsteiner antibodies)

These are autoantibodies directed against the P antigen system on red cells. They are responsible for a rare disorder known as paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria.

  • Neutrophils (and/or monocytes) have Phagocytosed erythrocytes. This is particularly common in paroxysmal cold haemoglobinuria

KEY TAKEAWAYS:

  • Schistocytes (Fragmented RBCs): These are the hallmark of Fragmentation syndrome, which can be caused by mechanical trauma to RBCs, leading to intravascular hemolysis. It can be due to macroangiopathic or microangiopathic hemolytic anemia.
  • Marked RBC Agglutination: This is characteristic of Cold antibody-induced hemolytic anemia, where cold agglutinins cause RBC clumping at low temperatures.
  • Erythrophagocytosis and RBC Agglutination: This points to Paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria, where cold hemolysins (Donath-Landsteiner antibodies) cause RBC destruction and phagocytosis by neutrophils/monocytes.

questions.text: Antibody in paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria is directed against the blood group antigen?
questions.solution:
Paroxysmal Cold Hemoglobinuria (PCH) is caused by Donath-Landsteiner antibodies, which are autoantibodies that specifically target the P antigen on red blood cells. This condition is a rare form of autoimmune hemolytic anemia where the antibody binds to RBCs at cold temperatures, leading to their destruction when the blood is warmed.

  • P antigen is found on the surface of red blood cells and is the target of the antibodies involved in PCH.

Incorrect Options:

  • A) MNO: These are blood group antigens found in the M, N, and O systems, but they are not the target of the antibody in paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria.
  • B) Rh: The Rh antigen is involved in Rh incompatibility (e.g., Rh disease of the newborn) but is not associated with paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria.
  • D) I: The I antigen is related to cold agglutinin disease, not paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria.

Key Takeaways:

  • Paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria involves Donath-Landsteiner antibodies directed against the P antigen on red blood cells.
  • This condition results in hemolysis at colder temperatures, often after exposure to cold.
  • The P antigen is specific to this rare autoimmune hemolytic anemia, while other blood group antigens (MNO, Rh, I) are not involved in PCH.

choices.text: Normal individuals show a score of 4
In aplastic anemia, NAP score is low
High NAP score is seen in Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria
In leukemoid reaction, the NAP score is high

questions.text: Choose the correct statement about Neutrophil alkaline phosphatase (NAP) from the following.
questions.solution:
Score is obtained by assessing the stain intensity in 100 consecutive neutrophils, with each neutrophil scored on a scale of 0-4 as follows:

0 - Negative, no granules

1 - Occasional granules scattered in the cytoplasm

2 - Moderate numbers of granules

3 - Numerous granules

4 - Heavy positivity with numerous coarse granules crowding the cytoplasm, frequently overlying the nucleus.

  • In normal individuals, it is rare to find any neutrophils with a score of 3, and a score of 4 should not be present. (Choice A)

KEY TAKEAWAYS:

  • High NAP score is seen in conditions like leukemoid reaction, which is a reactive increase in white blood cell count typically seen in infections or severe stress, and in polycythemia vera and Hodgkin's lymphoma.
  • Low NAP score is characteristic of paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH), aplastic anemia, and conditions like chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) in the chronic phase.
  • NAP score assessment: The score is based on the intensity of granules in neutrophils, with higher scores indicating more granules.

choices.text: It should be transfused within 24 h of irradiation
A cross match should be performed prior
Blood for transfusion should be leukocyte rich

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding intrauterine transfusion?
questions.solution:
INTRAUTERINE (FETAL) TRANSFUSIONS:

  • Blood for intrauterine transfusions should be
    • Leucodepleted (Choice D)
    • K negative
    • Irradiated to prevent transfusion-associated graft-versus-host disease
    • Should be transfused within 24 h of irradiation. (Choice A)
  • When providing red cells for intrauterine transfusion, an antiglobulin crossmatch should be performed using maternal plasma. (Choice B)
  • Intrauterine transfusion can result in fetomaternal haemorrhage (FMH) (Choice C) and hence sensitisation to new antigens, so antibody identification and quantification or titration must be performed on all maternal samples.
  • Maternal samples should be collected less than 72 h prior to the planned transfusion.
  • Red cells selected should be group O D-negative (except where maternal anti-c is present, then provide D-positive, c-negative) and K-negative (except where maternal anti-k (cellano) is present, then provide k-negative).

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Intrauterine transfusions (IUT) require leukodepleted blood to prevent transfusion-associated graft-versus-host disease, not leukocyte-rich blood. The blood should be irradiated and transfused within 24 hours. A crossmatch with maternal plasma is necessary for compatibility. IUT can cause fetomaternal hemorrhage (FMH), leading to maternal sensitization, so antibody screening is essential. Blood used should be K-negative and O-negative, with specific exceptions based on maternal antibodies.

choices.text: Buffers the end product of glycolysis (lactic acid)
Needed for ATP generation for viability of red cells
Substrate for red cell synthesis of ATP

questions.text: What is the function of dextrose in anticoagulant preservative solution?
questions.solution:
Anticoagulants used:

The different anticoagulants-preservative solutions available are

  • Citrate phosphate dextrose (CPD)
  • Citrate phosphate dextrose adenine (CPDA-1)
  • Acid citrate dextrose (ACD) is not used nowadays.

Functions of various chemicals used in anticoagulant-preservative solution

KEY TAKEAWAYS: The function of dextrose in anticoagulant-preservative solutions is to provide a substrate for ATP generation, which is essential for maintaining the viability of red blood cells. This ensures the cells remain functional during storage.

questions.text: t(11;14) and t(14;18) chromosomal translocation are indicative of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Mantle cell lymphoma

  • Small cleaved lymphoid cells
  • Translocation involving BCL1 is indicative of mantle cell lymphoma with t(11;14) (q13;q32).
  • Much more aggressive with poor prognosis, thus requiring a more intensive treatment.

Follicular lymphoma

  • Identification of BCL2 involvement implies a follicular lymphoma with t(14;18)(q32;q21).

KEY TAKEAWAYS:

  • t(11;14) translocation is associated with Mantle cell lymphoma, which involves the BCL1 gene and is characterized by small cleaved lymphoid cells.
  • t(14;18) translocation is indicative of Follicular lymphoma, involving the BCL2 gene.
  • Mantle cell lymphoma is typically more aggressive with a poor prognosis, requiring intensive treatment.

questions.text: Platelets are tiny, disc-shaped pieces of cells that are Found in the blood. Platelets are stored at:
questions.solution:
• Platelets require careful handling while collection, preparation, and transfusion.
  • The bags in which platelets are stored are made from gas-permeable plastic to allow sufficient oxygen to maintain aerobic respiration.
  • Platelets should be stored at room temperature 20-24°C with constant agitation for 5-7 days to maximize recovery and survival in vitro after transfusion. (Choice A)
  • Storage at low temperature leads to irreversible changes on the platelet membrane, resulting in phagocytosis.
  • Higher temperature may lead to an increase in bacterial infections.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Platelets should be stored at 20-24°C with constant agitation for 5-7 days to maintain their viability, as storage at lower or higher temperatures can cause irreversible damage or increase the risk of bacterial infections.

questions.text: The cytogenetic defect t(15;17) is associated with which of the following leukemia?
questions.solution:
• Acute myeloid leukemia is an acquired genetic mutation in stem cells lead to the proliferation of undifferentiated myeloid blasts.
  • Acute promyelocytic leukemia is a Type of acute myeloid leukemia.
  • It results from a translocation due to a rearrangement of genetic material resulting in the formation of chromosome t(15;17)(q24.1;q21.2).
  • Patients usually present with weakness, Fatigue, hemorrhage and frequent infections.
  • The diagnosis of APL is confirmed by the identification of the PML-RARA fusion gene.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: The t(15;17) translocation is associated with Acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL), a subtype of acute myeloid leukemia, resulting in the PML-RARA fusion gene. This defect leads to the proliferation of undifferentiated myeloid blasts.

questions.text: PAS-positive coarse granules are found in which kind of Leukemia?
questions.solution:
Cytochemical studies help in differentiating types of Leukemias.

Lymphoblasts usually reveal PAS-positive Granules.

PERIPHERAL SMEAR of Acute lymphoblastic leukemia:

RBCs: They show normocytic normochromic type of anemia.

WBCs: Total count is usually markedly increased. Few may present with pancytopenia. Blasts may replace normal myeloid series and can cause neutropenia.

Peripheral blood smear in acute lymphoblastic leukemia showing lymphoblasts. Inset in A shows lymphoblast with block positivity with PAS stain

  • Lymphoblasts: The minimum requirement for diagnosis by WHO criteria is 20% blasts or more. The morphologic distinctions between B and T require lymphocyte-specific markers.
  • Morphology of lymphoblasts:
    • Size: Larger than small lymphocyte
    • High nucleus-to-cytoplasmic ratio
    • Nucleus: It shows condensed chromatin.
    • Nucleoli are either absent or inconspicuous.
    • Cytoplasm: Scant to moderate agranular basophilic cytoplasm.
  • Platelets: Thrombocytopenia is common and is responsible for bleeding from skin and mucosa.

CYTOCHEMISTRY OF LYMPHOBLASTS

  • Periodic Acid Schiff (PAS) stain demonstrates cytoplasmic aggregates of PAS positive material (block positivity).
  • Myeloperoxidase negative.
  • Sudan Black B negative.


KEY TAKEAWAYS: PAS-positive coarse granules are characteristic of Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), where lymphoblasts show block positivity with the PAS stain. This helps differentiate ALL from other types of leukemia.

questions.text: Most sensitive test for disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) is:
questions.solution:
Fibrinogen degradation products (FDPs) are the most sensitive test for Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation (DIC). In DIC, excessive fibrin formation occurs, leading to fibrinolysis and the release of FDPs into the bloodstream. Elevated levels of FDPs indicate systemic fibrinolysis, which is a hallmark of DIC.

  • Normal range of FDP (Fibrin degradation product)
    • Healthy subjects have an FDP concentration of less than 10 μg/ml.
    • Concentrations between 10 and 40 μg/ml are seen in:
      • Acute venous thromboembolism
      • Acute myocardial infarction
      • Severe pneumonia
      • After major surgery
    • High levels are seen in
      • Systemic fibrinolysis associated with DIC (Disseminated intravascular coagulation)
      • Thrombolytic therapy with streptokinase.
  • DIC is the activation of the coagulation cascade, which leads to microthrombi and consumption of platelets and coagulation Factors (II, V, VIII, and fibrinogen).
  • DIC results from the Release of tissue thromboplastin or activation of the Intrinsic pathway.
  • Common causes:
    • Obstetric Complications (preeclampsia, retained fetus or abruptio Placentae)
    • Gram-negative sepsis malignancy
    • Acute Promyelocytic leukemia).

Incorrect Answers:

  • a) Platelet count: While platelet count can be decreased in DIC due to platelet consumption, it is not as sensitive as FDP for diagnosing the condition.
  • b) D-Dimer: D-Dimer is a breakdown product of cross-linked fibrin and is commonly elevated in DIC, but it is less specific and sensitive than FDPs.
  • d) PT (Prothrombin Time): PT may be prolonged in DIC due to consumption of clotting factors, but it is not as sensitive as FDPs in diagnosing DIC.

PT, APTT, and bleeding time are also increased. Fibrinogen platelet counts are decreased.

Fibrinogen Degradation products are the most sensitive test for disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).

Key Takeaways:

  • FDPs are the most sensitive test for detecting DIC.
  • DIC involves microthrombosis and the consumption of coagulation factors, leading to elevated FDPs.
  • Other tests like D-Dimer and PT are also important, but FDPs provide the earliest indication of DIC.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with pancytopenia, a markedly enlarged spleen and extramedullary hematopoiesis. He is found to have a JAK-2 mutation. What is the Diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Primary myelofibrosis is a clonal MPN characterized by a proliferation of predominantly megakaryocytes and granulocytes in the bone marrow. In the fully developed disease, the reactive marrow fibrosis replaces hematopoietic cells leading to cytopenias and extensive extramedullary haematopoiesis

In chronic myelofibrosis, blood smear shows Teardrop shaped red cells and normoblast.

  • JAK-2 mutations are commonly seen in chronic myelofibrosis.
  • This mutation is also seen in other chronic myeloproliferative Disorders (polycythemia vera and essential Thrombocythemia).

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Chronic myelofibrosis is a myeloproliferative disorder marked by JAK-2 mutations, pancytopenia, splenomegaly, and extramedullary hematopoiesis. Blood smears often show teardrop-shaped red cells and normoblasts, reflecting marrow fibrosis and cytopenias.

choices.text: It has a diameter of 1.5 to 3.5 micrometer
Alpha granules contain v WF & Fibronectin
Nucleus is bounded by typical lipid bilayer membrane
Outer membrane has three different types of granules

questions.text: Which of the following statement is incorrect about the platelets?
questions.solution:
PLATELETS:

  • These are small fragments of cytoplasm derived from megakaryocytes.
  • Diameter: 1.5 to 3.5 μm in diameter but may be larger in some disease states. (Choice A)
  • They do not contain a nucleus and are bounded by a typical lipid bilayer membrane. (Choice C)
  • Beneath the outer membrane lies the marginal band of microtubules, which maintain the shape of the platelet and depolymerise when aggregation begins.
  • The central cytoplasm is dominated by the three types of platelet granules: (choice D - membrane does not contain granules)
    • The δ (dense) granules
    • α granules and
    • Lysosomal granules.
  • The contents of these various granules exist the dense tubular system and the canalicular membrane system; the latter communicates with the exterior.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Platelets are small, non-nucleated cell fragments (1.5-3.5 μm) derived from megakaryocytes. They contain three types of granules: dense (δ), alpha (α), and lysosomal granules. The alpha granules contain important proteins like von Willebrand factor (vWF) and fibronectin. The platelet membrane is a typical lipid bilayer and does not contain granules. The granules are housed beneath the membrane and are involved in platelet function during aggregation.

questions.text: Choose the normal serum iron reference range for an adult male from the following.
questions.solution:
KEY TAKEAWAYS: In an adult male:

  • Serum Iron: 11-30 μmol/l (50-170 μg/dl)
  • Serum Ferritin: 30-300 ng/ml
  • TIBC: 45-80 μmol/l (250-450 μg/dl)
  • Hemoglobin: 13-17 g/dl

choices.text: Giant Metamyelocytes on bone marrow aspirate

questions.text: Which one of the following is incorrect lab test result in suspected cobalamin or folate deficiency?
questions.solution:
Laboratory tests for Megaloblastic anaemia

  • Full blood count - Macrocytosis (high MCV >110 fl) (choice A)
  • Blood film - Oval macrocytes, hypersegmented neutrophils (>5% with ≥5 lobes); Howell-Jolly bodies suggests hyposplenism and therefore coeliac disease as a cause of the deficiency (choice B)
  • Reticulocyte count - Absolute count low pretreatment (choice C)
  • Bone marrow aspirate - Megaloblastic erythropoiesis, giant metamyelocytes, hypersegmented neutrophils, ring sideroblasts infrequent (choice D)
  • Serum B12 < 180 ng/l suggestive of cobalamin deficiency
  • Serum folate - Low level, particularly if red cell folate also low confirms deficient state
  • Red cell folate - Low level, particularly if B12 deficiency is excluded

KEY TAKEAWAYS: In cobalamin or folate deficiency, lab results typically show macrocytosis (MCV >110 fl), hypersegmented neutrophils on the blood smear, and giant metamyelocytes on bone marrow aspirate. However, the reticulocyte count is usually low before treatment, not high, as seen in choice C. This helps differentiate megaloblastic anemia from other conditions with elevated reticulocyte counts.

choices.text: It is a sign of extravascular hemolysis
It is present in the form of grouped blue staining granules
It may persist for weeks after a haemolytic episode
Deposits of hemosiderin can be stained by perls reaction

questions.text: Which is the false statement regarding the demonstration of hemosiderin in urine?
questions.solution:
DEMONSTRATION OF HAEMOSIDERIN IN URINE

Method

  • Centrifuge 10 ml of urine at 1200 g for 10-15 min.
  • Transfer the deposit to a slide, spread out to occupy an area of 1-2 cm and allow to dry in the air.
  • Fix by placing the slide in methanol for 10-20 min and then stain by the method used to stain bone marrow films for haemosiderin.
  • Haemosiderin, if present, appears in the form of isolated or grouped blue-staining granules, usually from 1 to 3 μm in size; they may be both intracellular and extracellular. (Choice B)

Significance of haemosiderinuria

  • Haemosiderinuria is a sequel to the presence of haemoglobin in the glomerular filtrate.
  • It is a valuable sign of intravascular haemolysis (choice A) because the urine will be found to contain iron-containing granules even if there is no haemoglobinuria at the time.
  • However, haemosiderinuria is not found in the urine at the onset of a haemolytic attack even if this is accompanied by haemoglobinaemia and haemoglobinuria because the haemoglobin has first to be absorbed by the cells of the renal tubules.
  • It may persist for weeks after a haemolytic episode (choice C)

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Haemosiderin in urine is a sign of intravascular hemolysis, where iron-containing granules appear in the urine after hemoglobin is filtered through the glomeruli and absorbed by renal tubules. It can persist for weeks after a hemolytic episode, even if hemoglobinuria is no longer present. The granules appear as blue-staining clusters, and they can be stained with Perl's reaction. However, it is not a direct sign of extravascular hemolysis.

questions.text: Condition associated with decreased osmotic fragility from the following is?
questions.solution:
The osmotic fragility test gives an indication of the surface area/volume ratio of erythrocytes.

Its greatest usefulness is in the diagnosis of HS.

The test may also be used in screening for thalassaemia.

In thalassemia, the red blood cells are often microcytic and hypochromic due to defective hemoglobin production. These cells have a reduced surface area-to-volume ratio, which makes them less susceptible to osmotic lysis in hypotonic solutions compared to normal red blood cells. Consequently, red blood cells in individuals with thalassemia are more resistant to bursting when exposed to a hypotonic solution, leading to decreased osmotic fragility.

Conditions Associated with Increased Osmotic Fragility (OF)

  • Hereditary spherocytosis (HS)
  • Hereditary elliptocytosis (HE)
  • Hereditary stomatocytosis
  • Other inherited membrane abnormalities
  • Autoimmune haemolytic anaemia

Conditions Associated with Decreased Osmotic Fragility (OF)

  • Thalassaemia
  • Enzyme abnormalities
  • Hereditary xerocytosis
  • Iron deficiency

Why the other options are incorrect:

  • A) Autoimmune hemolytic anemia: In autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA), antibodies attack the red blood cells, causing them to become more fragile and prone to lysis in a hypotonic solution. This leads to increased osmotic fragility, not decreased.
  • C) Hereditary elliptocytosis: In hereditary elliptocytosis (HE), the red blood cells have an abnormal elliptical shape, which increases their fragility. These cells are more prone to rupture in a hypotonic solution, leading to increased osmotic fragility.
  • D) All of the above: This option is incorrect because only thalassemia is associated with decreased osmotic fragility, while AIHA and hereditary elliptocytosis are associated with increased osmotic fragility.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Thalassemia is associated with decreased osmotic fragility due to microcytic and hypochromic red blood cells, which are more resistant to rupture in hypotonic solutions. In contrast, conditions like hereditary spherocytosis and autoimmune hemolytic anemia show increased osmotic fragility due to more fragile red blood cells.

questions.text: Which is the specific test for hereditary spherocytosis from the following?
questions.solution:
• Tests that demonstrate red cell membrane defects:
    • Glycerol lysis time
    • Cryohaemolysis
    • Autohaemolysis
    • Membrane protein analysis
  • Osmotic fragility may be abnormal in any condition where spherocytes occur, it has been suggested that cryohaemolysis is specific for HS.
  • Cryohaemolysis is dependent on factors that are related to molecular defects of the red cell membrane rather than to changes in the surface area-to-volume ratio.
  • The test can be carried out on EDTA blood up to 1 day old.
  • Interpretation:
    • The range of cryohaemolysis In normal subjects to be 3-15%, The most normal samples give <3% lysis whereas in HS there was >20% lysis.
    • Increased lysis is not exclusive to HS and may be observed in hereditary stomatocytosis.

KEY TAKEAWAYS:

  • Cryohaemolysis is specific for diagnosing hereditary spherocytosis (HS) due to its focus on membrane defects rather than surface area-to-volume ratio.
  • It demonstrates increased lysis (>20%) in HS, while normal subjects show <3%.
  • Osmotic fragility can be abnormal in various conditions with spherocytes, but cryohaemolysis is more specific for HS.

questions.text: Which one of the following is not an Inherited abnormality that increase haemoglobin F concentration in adult life?
questions.solution:
• Increased haemoglobin F in adult life Haemoglobin production in man is characterised by two major switches in the haemoglobin composition of the red cells.
  • During the first 3 months of gestation, human red cells contain embryonic haemoglobins
  • During the last 6 months of gestation, red cells contain predominantly fetal haemoglobin.
  • The major transition from fetal to adult haemoglobin synthesis occurs in the perinatal period, and by the end of the first year of life, red cells have a haemoglobin composition that usually remains constant throughout adult life.
  • The major haemoglobin is then haemoglobin A, but there are small amounts of haemoglobins A2 And F.
  • Only 2-1.0% of total haemoglobin in adult human red cells is haemoglobin F and it is restricted to a few cells called 'F cells'.
  • Both the number of F cells and the amount of haemoglobin F per cell can be increased in various conditions, particularly if there is rapid bone marrow regeneration.

Increased HbF in adult life:

  • Hereditary persistence of fetal haemoglobin (HPFH) (choice A)
  • δβ thalassaemia (choice, B)
  • Inherited red cell aplasia
  • inherited aplastic anaemia (Blackfan-Diamond syndrome (choice C) and Fanconi anaemia)
  • juvenile myelomonocytic leukaemia and
  • some myelodysplastic syndromes.

A small but significant increase in haemoglobin F may occur in the presence of erythropoietic stress (haemolysis, bleeding, recovery from acute bone marrow failure) and in pregnancy.

KEY TAKEAWAYS:

  • Hereditary persistence of fetal hemoglobin (HPFH), δβ thalassemia, and Blackfan-Diamond syndrome can increase hemoglobin F in adults.
  • Thalassemia does not specifically increase hemoglobin F concentration.
  • Hemoglobin F levels are typically low in adults but can increase in response to conditions like erythropoietic stress or certain inherited disorders.

choices.text: Deficiency of factor II, VII, IX & X
Deficiency of all clotting factors except vWF
Deficiency of factors IX, X, XI & XII

questions.text: A 67 year old chronic alcoholic with known alcoholic cirrhosis presents with upper gastrointestinal hemorrhage. Bleeding is persistent, despite prolonged tamponade. A coagulation defect related to the liver disease is suspected. Which of the following abnormalities is most consistent with this possibility?
questions.solution:
The liver is the site of production of all coagulation factors except vWF, and severe hepatic dysfunction canthus be associated with multiple factor deficiencies, excluding vWF.

PATHOPHYSIOLOGY OF HEMOSTATIC DEFECT IN LIVER DISEASE IS COMPLEX:

  1. Deficient synthesis of coagulation factors in hepatocellular disease
  2. Deficient synthesis of vitamin k-dependent factors in biliary obstruction
  3. Synthesis of dysfunctional fibrinogen (dysfibrinogenemia)
  4. Decreased clearance of activated coagulation factors
  5. Defective platelet function due to raised fibrinogen/fibrin degradation products
  6. Disseminated intravascular coagulation.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: In liver disease, all coagulation factors except vWF are deficient, leading to bleeding. The liver synthesizes most coagulation factors, and dysfunction causes a broad coagulation defect, excluding vWF.

questions.text: Which of the following cause is not of acquired Thrombophilia?
questions.solution:
Thrombophilia is a hemostatic disorder in which there is a predisposition to thrombosis due to an inherited or acquired condition. It results from alteration in hemostatic constituents of blood.

  • Correct Answer (D) Factor V Leiden: Factor V Leiden is an inherited thrombophilia, not acquired. It is a genetic mutation of factor V that increases the risk of blood clots.

Why the other options are incorrect:

  • Option A (Oral contraceptives): Oral contraceptives are an acquired cause of thrombophilia as they increase the risk of venous thromboembolism by affecting the coagulation cascade, especially in women who smoke or are over 35 years old.
  • Option B (Antiphospholipid syndrome): Antiphospholipid syndrome is an acquired autoimmune condition in which antibodies target phospholipids and increase the risk of clot formation, making it a common cause of acquired thrombophilia.
  • Option C (Heparin induced thrombocytopenia): Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) is an acquired condition that results from an immune reaction to heparin, leading to thrombosis despite a low platelet count.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Factor V Leiden is inherited, while oral contraceptives, antiphospholipid syndrome, and heparin-induced thrombocytopenia are all acquired causes of thrombophilia, increasing the risk of thrombosis through different mechanisms.
